item.title: Major Site Overhaul - August 2025
item.description: After a long break, we've implemented major overhauls to the style and layout of the website, making the best use of GitHub Pages static hosting capabilities.
item.content:encoded:
After a long break from this site, we have some major overhauls of the style and layout of the website, making the best use of the GitHub Pages static hosting capabilities.

ğŸš€ New Additionsâ€‹

  • Docusaurus build tools - Modern static site generation
  • AI (Cursor) integration - To manage conversion process
  • Extensive cursor rules - Enforce high quality build pipelines
  • Quality assurance - Ensure all pages build without errors when converting from .ipynb or .py â†’ .md â†’ .html

ğŸ“¸ Historical Contextâ€‹

June 2019 - Original Siteâ€‹

August 2025 - MkDocs Version (v1)â€‹

ğŸ¯ Current Statusâ€‹

The final version is just a bit more refined, but we could probably have achieved the same thing with MkDocs. However, Docusaurus provides better integration with modern web development workflows and enhanced features for documentation and blogging.

ğŸ”„ Migration Processâ€‹

This migration involved:

  1. Content conversion from various formats to markdown
  2. Navigation restructuring for better user experience
  3. Build pipeline optimization for faster development cycles
  4. Quality enforcement through automated checks and AI assistance

This post marks the beginning of a new era for the learning platform, with improved tools and processes for content management.

item.title: Welcome
item.description: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.
item.content:encoded:
Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

Here are a few tips you might find useful.

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the blog directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to authors.yml.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

  • 2019-05-30-welcome.md
  • 2019-05-30-welcome/index.md

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

The blog supports tags as well!

And if you don't want a blog: just delete this directory, and use blog: false in your Docusaurus config.

item.title: Final June Update and Summer Planning - June 2019
item.description: Final update for June 2019 with reflection on progress and planning for summer learning activities.
item.content:encoded:

item.content:encoded:

ğŸ”® Future Learning Directionsâ€‹

ğŸ¯ Long-term Goalsâ€‹

Completing the initial learning phase and planning for advanced topics in machine learning, DevOps, and system architecture.

item.content:encoded:

This update reflects the ongoing journey through Harvard's CS50 course, building foundational programming skills through practical project work. Each problem set builds upon previous knowledge, creating a comprehensive understanding of computer science fundamentals.

Part of the ongoing CS50x 2019 learning journey - building practical programming skills through hands-on projects.

item.title: Advanced Features and Optimization - June 2019
item.description: Implementing advanced features and optimization techniques for web applications.
item.content:encoded:
ğŸš€ Advanced Feature Implementationâ€‹

Building on the basic functionality, this week focused on implementing advanced features and optimization techniques for the web applications.

ğŸ” Advanced Authenticationâ€‹

  • OAuth integration with social platforms

  • Session management and security

ğŸ“± Progressive Web App Featuresâ€‹

  • Service worker implementation

  • App-like experience on mobile devices

ğŸ¨ Advanced UI/UX Featuresâ€‹

  • Dark mode and theme switching
  • Advanced animations and transitions
  • Accessibility improvements and ARIA support
  • Internationalization and localization

âš¡ Performance Enhancementsâ€‹

  • Lazy loading and code splitting
  • Database connection pooling
  • Background task processing with Celery
  • Microservices architecture exploration

ğŸ” Monitoring and Analyticsâ€‹

  • User behavior tracking and analytics
  • Performance monitoring and alerting
  • Error tracking and logging
  • A/B testing and optimization

Implementing advanced features and optimization techniques to create professional-grade web applications.

item.title: Database Design and Management - May 2019
item.description: Learning database design principles and SQL integration with Python web applications.
item.content:encoded:
ğŸ—„ï¸ Database Fundamentalsâ€‹

Building on the web development focus, this week concentrated on database design principles and SQL integration with Python applications.

ğŸ“Š Database Design Principlesâ€‹

  • Normalization and data integrity
  • Entity relationships and modeling
  • Indexing strategies and performance
  • Data types and constraints

ğŸ Python Database Integrationâ€‹

SQLAlchemy ORMâ€‹

  • Object-relational mapping concepts
  • Model definition and relationships
  • Query building and optimization
  • Database migrations and versioning

Django ORMâ€‹

  • Model definitions and field types
  • Query sets and filtering
  • Database migrations and management
  • Admin interface integration

ğŸ” SQL Masteryâ€‹

  • Basic queries and data retrieval
  • Joins and relationship handling
  • Aggregation and grouping functions
  • Performance optimization techniques

ğŸš€ Practical Applicationsâ€‹

The learning combines theory with practice:

  • Designing database schemas for web applications
  • Implementing CRUD operations with Python
  • Performance testing and optimization
  • Real-world project development

Building comprehensive database skills to support full-stack web development with Python frameworks.

Advanced Algorithmsâ€‹

item.title: MIT 6.00.2x Course Progress - April 2019
item.description: Progress update on MIT 6.00.2x course with first problem set completion and plans for Python integration at work.
item.content:encoded:
ğŸ“š Course Progress Updateâ€‹

A little behind on the MIT 6.00.2x course, but finished first of three problems for the first problem set. The course focuses on:

  • Introduction to Computational Thinking and Data Science
  • Python programming fundamentals
  • Data analysis and visualization
  • Algorithmic thinking and problem solving

ğŸ¯ Access and Course Structureâ€‹

I was surprised a few weeks ago when I got access to the grader and problem sets since I thought they would be behind a paywall for me since EdX changed their access policy. It might be because I worked on the course for a few weeks last year in December.

ğŸ’¼ Work Integration Plansâ€‹

Might start using Python a bit more at work for a proof of concept project, but I'll still want to continue working on Python on my own, focusing more on areas not covered at work, such as:

  • Web development and frameworks
  • Advanced algorithms and data structures
  • Machine learning applications
  • Automation and scripting

ğŸ”„ Learning Strategyâ€‹

The approach balances practical work applications with personal development:

  • Work projects for immediate practical experience
  • Personal study for broader skill development
  • Course completion for structured learning
  • Project-based learning for hands-on application

Balancing MIT course progress with practical Python applications at work while maintaining focus on broader skill development.

item.title: Linux Command Line Mastery - March 2019
item.description: Advanced command line operations and shell scripting basics for Linux system administration and automation.
item.content:encoded:
ğŸš€ Advanced Command Line Skillsâ€‹

Building on the fundamentals established in previous weeks, this week focused on more advanced command line operations and shell scripting capabilities.

ğŸ”§ Shell Scripting Basicsâ€‹

  • Bash scripting fundamentals
  • Variable usage and environment setup
  • Control structures and loops
  • Function definition and usage

ğŸ› ï¸ System Administration Toolsâ€‹

Exploring essential Linux administration tools:

  • Package management with apt/yum
  • Service management with systemctl
  • User management and permissions
  • Network configuration and monitoring

ğŸ“Š Process and System Monitoringâ€‹

  • Process monitoring with ps, top, htop
  • System resource usage tracking
  • Log analysis and troubleshooting
  • Performance optimization techniques

ğŸ” Advanced File Operationsâ€‹

  • Text processing with sed, awk, grep
  • File searching and pattern matching
  • Archive management and compression
  • Backup strategies and automation

Advancing from basic Linux concepts to practical system administration skills and automation capabilities.

item.title: Site Setup Complete - March 2019
item.description: Initial site setup completed with basic directory structure, style, and topic portals. GitHub integration working and Linux journey planning begins.
item.content:encoded:
ğŸš€ Initial Site Foundationâ€‹

Definitely don't need to add a new site update file that often, maybe once a week at MOST. In the past week, basically this site was set up and I got the basic directory, style and topic portals set up.

ğŸ”§ Technical Setupâ€‹

GitHub was a pain to get working and I'm only using its most basic functionality, just whatever is sufficient to get things functional. The site now has:

  • Basic directory structure established
  • Styling and layout configured
  • Topic portals set up for different learning areas
  • GitHub integration working (basic functionality)

ğŸ“‹ To-Do Listâ€‹

  • Next site update: March 9, 2019. Basically every Saturday
  • Cover most of basic Linux topics in the coming weeks

ğŸ¯ Goals for Next Weekâ€‹

When I check back in a week I hope that I will make some major progress on Linux journey and make a decision on how I'll incorporate my prior Python notes - probably just exporting from OneNote as some sort of web page.

The beginning of a structured learning journey with weekly updates and clear goals for Linux and Python learning.
